message_1:
In a 10-round Centipede Game, player 1 starts by choosing to either "pass" or "take" a reward of $2. If player 1 decides to pass, player 2 gets the $2 reward and has the option to either pass or take a $4 reward on round 2. If player 2 passes, player 1 gets the $4 reward and has the option to either pass or take a $6 reward on round 3, and so on for the following rounds. If player 1 decides to take the $2 reward on round 1, the game ends and both players earn $1 each. 

What decision should player 1 make in the first round of the game (pass or take) in order to maximize their total earnings?
message_2:
To determine the best decision for player 1 in the first round, we need to consider the potential outcomes of the game. Let's analyze the game from the last round to the first round using backward induction.

In the last round (round 10), player 2 has the option to pass or take a $20 reward. If player 2 takes the reward, the game ends, and player 1 gets nothing. If player 2 passes, both players get $10 each. Since player 2 would prefer to get $20 rather than $10, they will take the reward in round 10.

Knowing this, in round 9, player 1 has the option to pass or take an $18 reward. If player 1 takes the reward, the game ends, and player 2 gets nothing. If player 1 passes, player 2 will take the $20 reward in round 10. Since player 1 would prefer to get $18 rather than nothing, they will take the reward in round 9.

Continuing this logic, we can see that each player will take the reward in their respective rounds, as they know the other player will take the reward in the next round.

Therefore, in the first round, player 1 should take the $2 reward to maximize their total earnings. If player 1 passes, player 2 will take the $4 reward in round 2, leaving player 1 with nothing.
